section.title: Maintenance Tasks
section.para: Zone data is signed and the parent zone has published your DS records — at this point your zone is officially secure. When other validating resolvers lookup information in your zone, they are able to follow the 12-step process as described in and verify the authenticity and integrity of the answers.

There is not that much left for you to do, as the DNS administrator, at an ongoing basis. Whenever you update your zone, BIND will automatically resign your zone with new RRSIG and NSEC or NSEC3 records, and even increment the serial number for you. If you choose to split your keys into a KSK and ZSK, the rolling of the ZSK is completely automatic. Rolling of a KSK or CSK requires manual intervention.

The only manual tasks for you to do are to monitor KSK or CSK key rolls and pass the new DS record to the parent zone - and you may not even have to do that if the parent can process CDS or CDNSKEY records.

section.title: The CDS and CDNSKEY Resource Records
section.para: Passing the DS record to the organization running the parent zone has always been recognised as a bottleneck in the key rollover process. To automate the process the CDS and CDNSKEY resource records were introduced.

The CDS and CDNSKEY records are identical to the DS and DNSKEY records, except in the type code and the name. When such a record appears in the child zone, it is a signal to the parent that it should update the DS it has for that zone. In essence, what happens is that the parent polls the child zone and notices the presence of either or both of the CDS and CDNSKEY records. It checks these records in the usual way i.e., that they are signed by a valid key for the zone. If the record(s) successfully validate a new DS record (copied from a CDS record or calculated from a CDNSKEY one) is added to the parent's DS RRset for the child.

section.title: Working with the Parent Zone (2)
section.para:
If your parent zone does support polling for CDS/CDNSKEY records, you are almost there. When BIND publishes these records, they will be uploaded and the DS record published in the parent.... we hope. At the time of writing (April 2020) BIND will not check for the presence of a DS record in the parent zone before completing the KSK or CSK rollover and withdrawing the old key. Instead, it assumes that the operation will be completed within the time period set by the parent-registration-delay value in the DNSSEC policy
So if the parent zone supports CDS/CDNSKEY, why did we have to manually upload the DS record when we first signed the zone? The answer is down to security. Until our zone was signed, the parent couldn't be sure that a CDS or CDNSKEY record it obtained really did come from the zone. So some other form of secure had to be used to obtain the information. .

If your parent doesn't support CDS/CDNSKEY, when a new KSK appears in your zone, you will have to supply the DNSKEY or DS record to the zone manually, probably using the same mechanism you used to upload the records for the first time.

Either way, you need to monitor the progress of a KSK or CSK roll. Look for the introduction of the CDS and CDNSKEY records in the zone. If required, send the DS record to the parent zone manually. And monitor the parent zone to ensure that the DS record appears at the correct time.
